ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: cryptography

We learned about several encryption schemes and definitions of security for them (building up to CPA security and CCA security). We learned about the cryptographic primitive of a One-Way-Function, and how these can be used to build Pseudorandom Generators, which can in turn be used to build Pseudorandom Functions and Pseudorandom Permutations. The latter two can be used to create CPA-secure and CCA-secure encryption schemes, respectively. We studied these extensively in the context of Private-Key Encryption, and we also moved on to Public-Key Encryption. We studied Message Authentication Codes and Digital Signatures. Throughout the course we wrote proofs of security. These proofs of security typically relied on technical assumptions such as FACTORING, DLOG, DDH, or RSA. We also often saw examples of insecure schemes and protocols, and discussed how an adversary can break them. In the last few lectures we discussed some advanced topics such as post-quantum cryptography and cryptocurrencies.

The fundamentals of cryptography: how to write formal security proofs, private key cryptography, public key cryptography, and special topics like zero-knowledge proofs, oblivious RAM, cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin), and secret sharing.
Number theory, notions of security, cryptographic primitives, how to write proofs, public key cryptography, private key cryptography, and cryptocurrency.
Knowledge of cryptography as well as its theory and implementation.
Knowledge of cryptographic primitives and protocols, and how to prove they are secure.
I learned about a variety of topics in cryptography, including different types of security, MACs, group theory, number theory, signatures, etc.
new insights into how cryptography works, even if I did already have previous knowledge it was very eye opening
introduction to the mathematical foundations of cryptography

I gained an intro background in cryptography and learned about an alternative proof style via adversarial parties that I think will be applicable to other areas of research I'm interested in. This class gave me a lot to think about!

We learned about symmetric key and public key cryptography. We saw rigorous definitions for security and constructions of cryptographic primitives like pseudorandom generators, functions, and permutations. The last two weeks gave us an introduction to some more modern developments in cryptography, like post-quantum cryptography, zero-knowledge proofs, etc. Throughout the class, we saw applications of probability in cryptography.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths are the flow of topics. Weaknesses are feedback and opportunity for practice.
familiarity with cryptography
The course was very well-taught but harshly organized. A more reasonable grading system would be an improvement.

I heard this course used to be pretty bad, but it's so much better now that Babis is teaching it. I learned so much in this class. The homeworks were a lot of work early in the semester, but the teaching staff made them a bit more manageable in the second half of the semester. The class is really well organized and you get detailed feedback on your homework one week after submitting it. If you're willing to put in some time, you'll learn a ton.

Strengths: Pretty interesting course, teaches you the fundamentals of cryptography, teaches you how to think critically, offers problem sessions for students to get help
Weaknesses: Not a lot of help for people without a background in number theory. Furthermore there is not a lot of resources provided to help students learn better.
Its a great course!

The professor is the biggest strength. He learns everyones name and is super enthusiastic about the material. The psets are also great, they are super fun and engaging. The midterm was a weakness it was out of nowhere and hard because we had no time, it would have been fair if time was not a problem. This was fixed in the final exam. Overall very few weaknesses

Perhaps there should be one lecture explaining oblivious transfer and garbled protocol, since they are "complete" for MPC, and then go on to explain ad-hoc solutions for problems like zero-knowledge, etc. The Byzantine agreement part is perhaps "too classic", there are significant progresses in this field since the 1980s.

I really like the content taught; it's really interesting especially if you have an interest in math. I thought that the exams were really difficult in comparison to the homework, which kind of threw me off guard.

strength: good balance between theoretical and practical within cryptography, good explanations and pace
weakness: not enough time to cover more stuff!

Strengths:
- very knowledgeable professor
- amazing TF
- solid curriculum

Improvements:
- Clearer lecture notes
- clarification of the actors/agents in individual security definitions. I have difficulty understanding which actor is conducting which step. Who is issuing the challenge? who is issuing the m_0 and m_1? the narrative is sometimes hard to follow
- a curve :)

The workload was a little low toward the end but too high at the beginning; the class could use some rebalancing

The material was very interesting and the psets were engaging. I think the lack of flexibility in grading was the big frustration of the class, we should not get zero credit for turning in a pset 5 minutes late, that and other things really decrease how seriously I take my final grade in this class as a reflection of my mastery of the material.

It was overall a great course. The information was presented clearly and the homework assignments were useful for solidifying our understanding of the concepts. It was clear how the different units tied together, so we were able to form a cohesive understanding of the material in the course. However, there were occasionally errors in the supplementary lecture notes and it would have been beneficial to have more office hours.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I don't know cs particularly well, but that didn't matter much in this course. I just think that the course is not very good. The content is interesting, but it's very hard to actually practice anything. The feedback on hw is almost non-existent, and we didn't have any practice problems at any point.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The material taught is very interesting.

Highly recommend. Cryptography was previously very mysterious to me, so it was great to learn how everything actually works. I think this class has the potential to be a real gem in the CS department now that Babis is teaching it.

I would only recommend this course to another student if they do not care about their grade, are genuinely interested in cryptography, and are adept at math. This class was very challenging for me and the workload was very intense. The class moves at a very fast pace and assumes the students is already good at things such as proofs. If the student wants a big challenge, I would recommend this class.
Yes, it is a fantastic course and Babis is a great professor.
Yes. A thorough understanding of cryptographic primitives, their function and limitation, is vital in the current information world.
Sort of. It's actually quite interesting to learn about cryptography in this proof/math-based way, but the exams are graded super harshly and are not straightforward at all.

Yes! You will learn about a really interesting and mathematical topic as opposed to just writing and debugging code. (We didn't do any coding after week 2 if I'm correct.) Cryptography is a really important topic in Computer Science. If you have taken cs 202 and are familiar with proofs, I highly recommend this course.
yes to another student in cs it is very relevant to how modern systems operate
Yes, assuming talley is still TF

I feel like this class opened up a new playground for me, I hadn't had rigorous exposure to cryptography prior and I feel like I can engage with it now in a very fulfilling way. I highly recommend it!

I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is interested in Theoretical CS or just wants to see a bit more math in a CS class. It is a good introductory Cryptography course, and you get to learn about a wide range of topics in Cryptography (with some depth, though the textbook includes more details that we didn't cover in class). The workload of the class was considerably higher in the 1st half of the semester (requiring a lot of time), so I am not sure what the workload will be like when the class will be taught again.
